Chatting with the dude last night is a white belt. He's training four to five times a week quite a bit
Pretty consistent guy strong on the mats fit strong dude good shape
Was talking to me about some hip pain that he's been experiencing and it was mostly through like his his kind of inner fires and also front of a hip
Really common for Jitsu, right?
I'm sure if you're watching this you trained Jitsu
You can identify with having experienced pain through the inside of the hip like the groin and through the hip flexes before
So he was asking me what I think you should do and I asked the guy what he does
Besides Jitsu training and he said I do a shitload of yoga
So it's like I do a bunch of yoga and I do kind of power style yoga
So it keeps me you know pretty strong and there's a lot of squatting single leg squatting that kind of thing in there
and
Sort of dug a little bit deeper and so I was quizzing him on if he does
Anything relevant to the inside of the fire so take like the Kossak squat
You've done the Kossak squat. We're talking more about building this adductor or this this inner fire strength right and
Mobility at the same time and he doesn't do a lot of that. So I was like oh well, that's that's somewhere
To start investigating so let's start doing some of that
But then the other thing I asked was if he deadlift at all and this is really if we think of this kind of more central to human movement
It's like do you do any kind of loaded hinging?
And he doesn't right because he does yoga so they don't there's no real external weights involved
now
I've experienced of all of my years of coaching people that when you
Avoid some kind of loaded hinging like a deadlift or any variation of the deadlift you miss out on a certain amount of glute and lower back development
That really just helps helps to keep the spine and the hips in good shape and in a sport like Jitsu
Where we're building huge amounts of strength through the inner fire and through the groin right because you think about the guard
Particularly close guard, which you're playing a lot when you're when you're a white belt and when you knew it to the game
You it's like death grip with the legs
You're squeezing your knees together. You fucking holding someone in there for you know as long as you can right
You're building huge amounts of strength on the inside of your thighs or the inside aspect of the hip
If you're not deadlifting or something similar to that then you're not building strength on the outside of the hip right
You're not building strength through the glutes through the lower back as much and what that means is you develop an imbalance
And imbalance usually leads to some kind of injury
So a lot of what we do in the ballproof program is about restoring balance to certain areas, right?
So what I said to this guy was like man, let's get some Kaseyck squats done
Let's make that a regular thing even if it's just something you put into your warm-ups a few days a week
But let's start doing some deadlifting and if that means that he has to go to the gym once a week and deadlift a barbell
You know does like whatever five six sets and calls it a day that
Done consistently over a long period of time is just going to help to balance out the strength that he's developing on the other side of the hips
And in the long term it's going to give him a good hip balance and it's going to reduce his chances of injury
